Title: Input organization of distal and proximal forelimb areas in the monkey primary motor cortex: a retrograde double labeling study
Abstract: The present double-labeling study was designed to demonstrate the morphological framework for motor control in coordinated distal and proximal forelimb movements, which may partly, at least, depend on corticocortical and thalamocortical inputs to the forelimb area in the primary motor cortex. After intracortical microstimulation mapping of the forelimb area in the primary motor cortex of four macaque monkeys, a retrograde tracing study with fluorescent dyes was attempted to label simultaneously neurons in cortical and subcortical sites projecting to the distal forelimb representation area and those projecting to the proximal representation area of the primary motor cortex. Neurons projecting to distal and proximal forelimb parts of the primary motor cortex were largely separate in the following areas: the premotor area, primary somatosensory area, secondary somatosensory area, area 5, and thalamus. In contrast, there was no precise topographic organization of labeled projection neurons in the following areas: the supplementary motor area, cingulate motor area, primary motor cortex adjacent to the injection sites, claustrum, and basal nucleus of Meynert. The present study revealed that the forelimb area of the primary motor cortex receives both segregated and intermixed inputs from cortical and subcortical sources. In particular, the fact that the forelimb area of the primary motor cortex receives topographically organized inputs from the premotor area and nontopographically organized inputs from the supplementary motor area and cingulate motor area indicates possible different functional roles of frontal premotor areas in control of coordinated distal and proximal forelimb movements.

@Methods.Comments: "Since essentially similar retrograde labeling was observed in all monkeys, we describe the distribution of retrogradely labeled neurons seen in a representative case (Monkey Ma) below." (p. 200)

@Injections.Citation: "...In all cases, FB was injected deeply into the anterior bank of the CS, where digit movements are represented. In the first case (Monkey Ma), DY was injected into two sites in the arm-movement area of MI on the surface of the precentral gyrus (Fig. 1b). The areas of diffusion of FB and DY were approximately 2 mm in diameter, and were restricted to the digit-movement area and the arm-movement area, respectively. In the second case, tracer injections were placed in similar areas (not represented). In the third case (Monkey Fu), NY injection in the proximal forelimb-movement area was placed into the more rostral surface of the precentral gyrus (Fig. 1c). In this case, labeled glial cells were observed around the neuronal nuclei retrogradely labeled with NY. Nevertheless, neuronal and glial cells were readily distinguishable. In the fourth case case (Monkey Sh), the DY injection in the proximal forelimb-movement area was placed deep into the anterior bank of the precentral gyrus (Fig. 1d). Since essentially similar retrograde labeling was observed in all monkeys, we desrcibe the distribution of retrogradely labeled neurons seen in a representative case (Ma) below." (p. 200)

publication.title: Input organization of distal and proximal forelimb areas in the monkey primary motor cortex: a retrograde double labeling study
publication.abstract: The present double-labeling study was designed to demonstrate the morphological framework for motor control in coordinated distal and proximal forelimb movements, which may partly, at least, depend on corticocortical and thalamocortical inputs to the forelimb area in the primary motor cortex. After intracortical microstimulation mapping of the forelimb area in the primary motor cortex of four macaque monkeys, a retrograde tracing study with fluorescent dyes was attempted to label simultaneously neurons in cortical and subcortical sites projecting to the distal forelimb representation area and those projecting to the proximal representation area of the primary motor cortex. In contrast, there was no precise topographic organization of labeled projection neurons in the following areas: the supplementary motor area, cingulate motor area, primary motor cortex adjacent to the injection sites, claustrum, and basal nucleus of Meynert. The present study revealed that the forelimb area of the primary motor cortex receives both segregated and intermixed inputs from cortical and subcortical sources. In particular, the fact that the forelimb area of the primary motor cortex receives topographically organized inputs from the premotor area and nontopographically organized inputs from the supplementary motor area and cingulate motor area indicates possible different functional roles of frontal premotor areas in control of coordinated distal and proximal forelimb movements.
